citations.narrative:
The facility failed to maintain housing facilities in good repair.
- A portion of the shifting shoot for two tigers contained areas of thick flaking black paint and rust.
- Netting was installed over the cheetah exhibit to catch falling items from a gondola ride over the enclosure after an
incident in 2022 resulted in the death of an adult male cheetah (“Santiago"). However, an approximately five foot in length
gap is present between the outer wall of the enclosure and the end of the netting, leaving a gap that allows access into
the area that houses the animals.
Failure to maintain housing facilities in good repair can affect the structural integrity of the enclosure which may lead to
injury or harm of the animal. Housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect
the animals from injury and to contain the animals.

An insect infestation was located in multiple enclosures and food storage areas throughout the facility.
- Lines of ants were observed trailing into two enclosed stalls that housed giant anteaters. A cockroach was also observed
in the drain outside the enclosures.
- In the education building, enclosures that contained a military macaw, a white fronted amazon and a kookaburra
contained lines of ants in the cage bottoms, on perches and on food.
- The A6 Barn (Asia/Africa Forest) contained trails of ants that were observed along walls
that houses a male bongo.
- In the A8 Barn (North America) a barrel that contained pelleted herbivore food harbored ants.
Insect pests can cause contamination and disease as well as discomfort to the animals. The facility must establish and
maintain a safe and effective program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests. Correct
by maintaining an effective program by August 9, 2024.

Multiple enclosures are not preventing wildlife from entering primary enclosures.
- Two wild starlings and one wild squirrel were observed in the primary enclosure that contained a scarlet macaw and a
blue-and-gold macaw.
- One wild squirrel was observed in the primary enclosure that contained a blue-and-gold macaw.
Prevention of wildlife from entering a primary enclosure prevents the transmission of disease, parasites, and pests.
Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they restrict other animals from the entering the
enclosure.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
The facility failed to maintain housing facilities in good repair.  
 
- A portion of the shifting shoot for two tigers contained areas of thick flaking black paint and rust.  
 
- Netting was installed over the cheetah exhibit to catch falling items from a gondola ride over the enclosure after an 
incident in 2022 resulted in the death of an adult male cheetah (“Santiago"). However, an approximately five foot in length 
gap is present between the outer wall of the enclosure and the end of the netting, leaving a gap that allows access into 
the area that houses the animals.  
 
Failure to maintain housing facilities in good repair can affect the structural integrity of the enclosure which may lead to 
injury or harm of the animal. Housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect 
the animals from injury and to contain the animals. 
3.131(d) 
   
Sanitation. 
An insect infestation was located in multiple enclosures and food storage areas throughout the facility.  
 
- Lines of ants were observed trailing into two enclosed stalls that housed giant anteaters. A cockroach was also observed 
in the drain outside the enclosures.  
- In the education building, enclosures that contained a military macaw, a white fronted amazon and a kookaburra 
contained lines of ants in the cage bottoms, on perches and on food. 
- The A6 Barn (Asia/Africa Forest) contained trails of ants that were observed along walls  
that houses a male bongo.  
- In the A8 Barn (North America) a barrel that contained pelleted herbivore food harbored ants. 
 
Insect pests can cause contamination and disease as well as discomfort to the animals. The facility must establish and 
maintain a safe and effective program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests. Correct 
by maintaining an effective program by August 9, 2024.

3.153(a)(1)(iv)  Repeat
   
Primary enclosures. 
Multiple enclosures are not preventing wildlife from entering primary enclosures.  
 
- Two wild starlings and one wild squirrel were observed in the primary enclosure that contained a scarlet macaw and a 
blue-and-gold macaw.  
 
- One wild squirrel was observed in the primary enclosure that contained a blue-and-gold macaw.  
 
Prevention of wildlife from entering a primary enclosure prevents the transmission of disease, parasites, and pests. 
Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they restrict other animals from the entering the 
enclosure. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
